item.title: Lots of Oil, Little Production: What to Know About Venezuelan Energy
item.description: The South American country increasingly at odds with the Trump administration has the world’s largest oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Lazaro Gamio
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Video of Boat Strike Shows Survivors Waving Before Fatal Follow-Up Attack
item.description: The new detail further complicates the military’s explanations for its actions during the Sept. 2 strike in the Caribbean Sea.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Charlie Savage
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Adm. Frank M. Bradley, left, the top Special Operations commander, showed senior lawmakers a more complete video of the Sept. 2 strike and described his decision to order follow-up strikes during classified sessions on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Wants Maduro to Go. Here’s Who Could Replace Him in Venezuela.
item.description: Several senior Venezuelan officials and opposition politicians would have a claim to power in a transition, but all would face difficulties.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela holding a sword during a speech last month. Should he end up losing power, his potential replacement would be largely determined by the manner of his departure.

item.title: How the U.S. Focus on Fentanyl Helped Fuel the Cocaine Trade’s Resurgence
item.description: Across Latin America, cocaine trafficking has surged as Washington has prioritized combating fentanyl. Times reporters traveled to Ecuador to see how criminal groups are wreaking havoc.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jon Nazca/Reuters
item.media:description: The police in Spain displaying tons of cocaine last year at the port in Algeciras after it was transported in a container from Ecuador.

item.title: The ‘Cocaine Superhighway’ Fueled by the U.S. Focus on Fentanyl
item.description: As Washington made combating fentanyl a priority, cocaine trafficking has surged. Nowhere have the ripples been felt like in Ecuador, where criminal groups have run rampant.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, José María León Cabrera and Daniele Volpe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a car bombing in Guayaquil, Ecuador. Car bombs have become common, killing and terrorizing civilians, and gangs frequently clash with the military and the police.

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Employees working on battery units at the solar project, which is owned by AES, a Virginia company that holds utilities and power plants across the world.

item.title: Second Strike Scrutiny Obscures Larger Question About Trump’s Boat Attacks
item.description: Congress is focusing on two deaths in one strike. But nine other people died in that same attack, and the United States has killed 87 in all. Were any of those killings legal?
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Adm. Frank M. Bradley attended a classified meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Trump Trumpets Peace in Africa Amid War on Drug Boats, in Day of Dissonance
item.description: President Trump presided over a Congo-Rwanda peace deal on the same day his administration was being questioned about potential war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump trumpeted a peace agreement while hosting President Paul Kagame of Rwanda and President Felix Tshisekedi of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Stellantis Is in Default for Moving Jeep Production to U.S., Canada Says
item.description: The automaker switched production from Ontario in a bid to please President Trump. But the company defaulted on contracts covering hundreds of millions of dollars in assistance, Canada said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stellantis’s plant in Brampton, Canada. The European-based automaker also produces vehicles under the Chrysler, Dodge and Ram brands in North America.

item.title: Groups Express Anixety as Trump Threatens to Derail U.S.-Mexico-Canada Trade Pact
item.description: Hearings that began Wednesday in Washington reflected anxiety over the future of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact and whether the president could end up scrapping it.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Though President Trump negotiated and signed the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, he said this year that he wanted to make it a “much better deal.”

item.title: The Furor Over Trump’s Boat Attacks and a Particular Follow-Up Strike, Explained
item.description: Bipartisan congressional oversight is underway, but for now is focusing on narrow details about one missile instead of broader legal issues.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s orders regarding a lethal Sept. 2 attack on a boat in the Caribbean Sea are under scrutiny.

item.title: Trump’s Former Campaign Manager Assisted Honduran Presidential Candidate
item.description: Brad Parscale advised the campaign of Nasry Asfura, a right-wing candidate who was endorsed by the U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel, David C. Adams and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Parscale managed President Trump’s 2020 re-election campaign.

item.title: U.S. Military’s Boat Strikes Planning Takes On New Significance
item.description: The details could raise questions about who was responsible for a follow-up strike on Sept. 2 — the commander who ordered it or the defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: On orders from President Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the U.S. military has attacked 21 boats in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, killing 83 people.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Threat of Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has warned that the United States could soon expand its attacks from boats near the coast to targets inside Venezuela, but he has also spoken by phone to its leader.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro in Caracas in November. According to multiple people close to the Venezuelan government, Mr. Maduro believes he can remain in control and ride out the gravest threat to his 12-year rule.

item.title: Cold Weather Forecast to Bring Chilliest Temperatures of the Season
item.description: There’s no denying it. It’s really December.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff and Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: Matt Rourke/Associated Press
item.media:description: The cold weather is expected to linger in the Midwest and spread across the Mid-Atlantic and into the Northeast.

item.title: Canada Turns to the World’s Polar Bear Capital to Defend its Arctic
item.description: The tiny town of Churchill has two of Canada’s largest pieces of Arctic infrastructure, but years of neglect have left them in poor shape amid growing superpower rivalry in the region.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tundra outside Churchill, Manitoba, the so-called polar bear capital of the world.

item.title: Eugene Hasenfus, Gunrunner Who Exposed Iran-Contra Plot, Dies at 84
item.description: He emerged out of obscurity when his cargo plane was shot down while illegally ferrying arms to Nicaraguan rebels, setting off a scandal that tarnished the Reagan and Bush White Houses.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.media:credit: Lou Dematteis/Reuters
item.media:description: Eugene Hasenfus after he was captured by Sandinista soldiers in October 1986. His plane ferrying supplies to right-wing rebels in Nicaragua had been shot down. Parachuting to safety, he was the only crewman to survive.

item.title: Juan Orlando Hernández, Former President of Honduras, Is Freed From Prison After Trump Pardon
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández was convicted of flooding the United States with cocaine and had been sentenced to 45 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum, Maggie Haberman, Kenneth P. Vogel and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández, the former president of Honduras, at the U.N. General Assembly in 2018.

item.title: Maduro Faces His Ultimate Fight as Trump Threatens Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: President Trump’s threat of military action has confronted President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela with the gravest challenge of his crisis-ridden reign.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela during a rally in Caracas on Monday.

item.title: Beta Will Sell Motors to Another Electric Aircraft Company
item.description: The deal with a company owned by Embraer gives Beta Technologies an additional source of revenue as it develops its own electric aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA
item.media:credit: Kylie Cooper/Reuters
item.media:description: An electric aircraft made by Beta Technologies, a start-up based in Vermont.

item.title: Large Winter Storm Brings Snow and Ice to Northeast and Mid-Atlantic
item.description: Hazardous winter weather was expected through early Wednesday, according to forecasters. The storm had dropped a wintry mix of precipitation across the Midwest overnight.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch, Judson Jones and Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Kiichiro Sato/Associated Press

item.title: Trump Alleges Fraud, Without Evidence, in Honduras Election
item.description: Honduras was on edge after tallies showed two candidates separated by about 500 votes. Then President Trump claimed that officials were rigging results.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Jeff Ernst
item.media:credit: Moises Castillo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Soldiers carrying ballot boxes from rural polling stations at an airport in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Monday.

item.title: Son of El Chapo Pleads Guilty to Kidnapping Father’s Former Cartel Partner
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán López admitted to having the once-untouchable drug kingpin Ismael Zambada García abducted and flown to the United States, among a sweeping set of other crimes.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Robert Chiarito
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: A plane believed to have been used to kidnap the drug kingpin Ismael Zambada García in Santa Teresa, N.M., last year.

item.title: Trump Becomes the Wild Card in Razor-Thin Honduras Election
item.description: President Trump warned that if his favored candidate didn’t win, the United States would “not be throwing good money after bad” at the country.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign poster for Nasry Asfura, the right-wing candidate backed by President Trump, last month on a street in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

item.title: Inside the Bird-Flu Vaccine Trial for Monk Seals
item.description: After the virus returned to Hawaii this fall, testing the shots in the endangered seal species became urgent.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Loren Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: What Jamaica Wants After Deadly Hurricane? Visit Us, Island Says.
item.description: Tourism accounts for nearly a third of Jamaica’s economy, so officials are rushing to reopen dozens of hotels in time to salvage the vital winter travel season.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Erin Schaff
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kellanie Kerr working by flashlight at a tourist shop this month in Negril, Jamaica.

item.title: College Student Is Deported During Trip Home for Thanksgiving
item.description: Any Lucia López Belloza, 19, was detained by immigration agents at the Boston airport before a flight to surprise her family in Texas for Thanksgiving. She is now in Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Todd Pomerleau
item.media:description: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas.

item.title: Trump-Endorsed Candidate and Sportscaster Lead Honduran Presidential Race
item.description: Electoral authorities said partial results showed the two conservative candidates were virtually tied — and far ahead of the governing left-wing party.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Jeff Ernst
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump endorsed Nasry Asfura, one of the right-wing candidates for the Honduran presidency.

item.title: In Announcing Pardon of Drug Trafficker While Threatening Venezuela, Trump Displays Contradictions
item.description: President Trump’s statements on social media less than 24 hours apart showed the dissonance in his campaign against drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump spoke during a video call with military service members on Thursday.

item.title: Colleen Jones, Curling Champion and Broadcaster, Dies at 65
item.description: She won two world titles and six Canadian national championships, and was also a television anchor, reporter and commentator.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Andy Clark AC/Reuters
item.media:description: Colleen Jones during a curling match in 2002. She was inducted into Canada’s Sports Hall of Fame in 2016.

item.title: Trump Declares Venezuelan Airspace Closed
item.description: President Trump said days earlier that the United States could “very soon” expand its campaign of killing people at sea suspected of drug trafficking to attacking Venezuelan territory.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump spoke with Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader, last week, according to two people with knowledge of the discussion.

item.title: Fresh Reporting on Asylum Seekers at the U.S.-Canadian Border
item.description: Canada has made its border with the United States tougher to cross. Here’s what we learned through monthlong reporting on a single case.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Book of Lives: A Memoir of Sorts (Book)
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahel Negassi at her new home in Kitchener, Ontario. She has applied for her Ontario nurse permit, and she hopes to be able to work soon.

item.title: Latin American Leaders Face Both Trump and Voters Deported by the U.S.
item.description: The upcoming election in Honduras shows how politicians must balance cooperation with the Trump administration with their obligation to undocumented citizens in the United States who may be deported.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delmar Méndez, 53, his partner and their 3-year-old son were deported from the United States in February after their asylum claim was denied, they said.
